Authors:
Leonardo Delgado-Cerrone, Pedro Mondino-Hintz, Sandra
Alaniz-Ferro
Title:
At least eight Botryosphareaciae species cause stem canker,
die-back and fruit rot on apple in Uruguay
Abstract:
Species of Botryosphaeriaceae affect several woody hosts
worldwide, including fruit crops. Their presence on apple has been
associated with stem canker and fruit rot. In Uruguay, these symptoms
are observed frequently, and, particularly in the last decade, stem
cankers have become major problems causing important economic losses. In
this study, 34 apple orchards were visited and the symptoms were
carefully observed. The presence of stem canker, die-back and fruit rot
caused by Botryosphaeriaceae family members was consistently observed. A
total of 91 Botryosphaeriaceae isolates were obtained from samples
collected with these symptoms and were characterized. The species were
identified by means of phylogenetic analysis of the ITS region and the
TEF-1Î± gene and phenotypical characterizations. Eight species were
detected, Botryosphaeria dothidea, Neofusicoccum parvum, N. luteum, N.
australe, Diplodia seriata, D. intermedia, D. pseudoseriata and
Lasiodiplodia theobromae; most of them were isolated from stem and
fruit. The predominant species were B. dothidea and D. seriata. Isolates
of the all Botryosphaeriaceae species were able to cause symptoms in the
stems and fruits of the apple inoculated, indicating that they can
indiscriminately infect either of the two apple tissues. The most severe
symptoms were caused by L. theobromae, N. parvum and N. luteum. These
results represent an important advancement in the knowledge of this
familyâs effect on apple crops in Uruguay.
